title: 105_hr4182
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE." is a concise summary of the main findings and objectives of the section. The Congress recognizes the significance of the Brown v. Board of Education decision, the integration of the "Little Rock Nine" at Central High School, and the architectural beauty of the school building. Central High School, recognized as the most beautiful high school building in America, was designated a national historic landmark in 1982 for its role in the civil rights movement. The school's inclusion in the National Park System aims to preserve its significance in the desegregation of Southern schools. The purpose of this Act is to preserve and protect Central High School. The Act aims to preserve Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas, and its role in the integration of public schools and the civil rights movement in the United States. Establishment of Central High School National Historic Site. The Little Rock Central High School national historic site is established as a unit of the National Park System in Arkansas. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the site in accordance with relevant laws. The Little Rock Central High School national historic site is established as a unit of the National Park System in Arkansas. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private agencies for the site's purposes. A general management plan must be prepared within 2 years of funds availability. The Secretary of School Museum, Inc. must prepare a general management plan for the historic site within 2 years. They are authorized to acquire lands within the site with consent from the owner, except for lands owned by the State of Arkansas or a political subdivision, which can only be acquired by donation or exchange. The Secretary must consult with the Little Rock School District to ensure the historic site's administration does not interfere with Central High School's educational use. The theme study on desegregation in public education is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary is required to prepare a national historic landmark theme study on the history of desegregation in public education within 2 years. The study aims to identify sites that commemorate key events in the movement for racial desegregation. Additionally, the study will provide opportunities for education and research. The theme study will prioritize sites for national historic landmark designation related to desegregation in public education. It will also recommend ways to connect these sites for educational and research purposes, and suggest cooperative agreements with educational institutions. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions, public history organizations, or civil rights organizations knowledgeable about desegregation in public education to prepare the theme study. The theme study will be part of the general management plan for the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums may be appropriated as necessary for this Act.
